questions.question: Which of the following receptors is a ligand-gated ion channel?
Which of the following statements is false regarding triptans?

options.B: No action on adrenergic or cholinergic or dopaminergic receptors
options.D: They are used for prophylaxis of migraine

questions.explanation: Triptans are not used in prophylaxis of migraine. They are indicated in the management of acuteattacks of migraine.•Drugs used in prophylaxis of migraine are :Beta-blocker - Propranolol, metoprolol• Antidepressant - Amitriptyline, nortriptyline.• Anticonvulsant - Topiramate, valproate• Serotonergic drug - Pizotifen• Antihistamine - Flunarizine• Angiotensin receptor blocker - candesartan

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presented to the ER with an acute attack of migraine. You decide toadminister a long-acting triptan. Which among the following do you choose?
questions.explanation: Frovatriptan is a long-acting triptan among other triptans.Headache recurrences in an attack are less with longer-acting triptans like frovatriptan andnaratriptan but onset of action may be slow.

questions.question: A patient of migraine has come to the OPD for follow up. She tells you that she gets verynauseous during the attacks and is not being able to take the oral drug. You decide toprescribe an intranasal formulation instead. Which of the following antimigraine agents willyou not choose?713
questions.explanation: Naratriptan is not available for intranasal administration. It is available only for oraladministration.

questions.question: After the administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nauseaand vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness at the tips of her fingers thateventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated?
questions.explanation: Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effectsof dihydroergotamine.The numbness progressing to bluish discolouration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion.It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of719dihydroergotamine.Contraindications for ergotamine:••Peripheral vascular diseaseCoronary artery disease• Uncontrolled hypertension• Fever and/or sepsis•Pregnancy• Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.question: A patient has just been diagnosed with migraine. Which of the following drugs can youprescribe for prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: Topiramate is used in the prophylaxis of migraine. Long-term use of topiramate can cause weightloss.The drugs that have been approved by the FDA for the preventive treatment of migraine include:•• Propranolol•Timolol• Sodium valproate•⚫ TopiramateOptions A and B - Sumatriptan, a 5HT1B/1D agonist is a first-line agent for the termination ofacute attacks. Ergotamines are also used in the termination of acute attacks.Option C - Domperidone is indicated as an adjuvant in acute attacks. Acute attacks are associatedwith gastric stasis and an increased incidence of nausea and vomiting. It is helpful in reducinggastrointestinal effects. It can also increase gastrointestinal absorption of other antimigraineagents that are not absorbed due to gastric stasis.

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine?

options.D: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.explanation: Colchicine acts by binding to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration.Colchicine produces its anti-inflammatory effects by binding to the intracellular protein tubulin.This prevents the polymerization of tubulin into microtubules which is necessary for leukocytemigration and phagocytosis. Inhibition of microtubule formation prevents granulocyte migrationand also arrests cell division at G1 phase.

questions.question: 714Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.explanation: Colchicine inhibits neutrophil (granulocyte) recruitment.720Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerisation of microtubules by binding to tubulin. Thisreduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotacticfactors by activated neutrophils, thus reducing the inflammatory response overall.Colchicine is used in gout and Mediterranean fever.

questions.question: A patient with chronic tophaceous gout was prescribed sulfinpyrazone. What is themechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation: Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent that promotes excretion of uric acid. It is used to decrease thebody pool of urate in patients with gout. They act by inhibiting the organic anion transporter thatis involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules.•Uricosuric agents used in gout are:• Probenecid•SulfinpyrazoneBenzbromarone• LesinuradUricosuric therapy should be initiated in gouty patients with underexcretion of uric acid and whenallopurinol or febuxostat is contraindicated or when tophi are present. Therapy should not bestarted until 2-3 weeks after an acute attack.

questions.question: A middle-aged obese man has presented to the OPD with acute pain around his left firstmetatarsophalangeal joint. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. X-ray is givenbelow. Which drug is commonly used as initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute onchronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout.In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibiturate crystal phagocytosis.Option A - Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It isuricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.Option C - Allopurinol is used for prophylaxis of gout.Option D - NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated withcolchicine.

questions.question: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was diagnosed with tumour lysis syndrome. She wasadministered rasburicase. Which group does this drug belong to?
questions.explanation: Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase which converts uric acid into soluble and inactiveallantoin. It is more effective in reducing the urate level than allopurinol.Recombinant uric acid oxidase is available as rasburicase and pegloticase. It is produced bygenetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain. They are indicated in gout only for chronicrefractory gout. It is primarily indicated for hyperuricemia associated with tumor lysis syndrome.721Pegloticase is a recombinant pegylated uric acid oxidase that is indicated for treatment of severe,treatment-refractory, chronic gout and also prophylaxis of gout.

questions.question: You have prescribed the first-line urate-lowering drug to a patient with chronic gout. Whichof the following is true about this drug?
questions.explanation: Allopurinol is recommended as the first-line urate-lowering agent in all patients with gout. It isa purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase enzyme.It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acidlevels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. The metabolite of allopurinol calledoxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.

questions.question: A patient was on treatment with indomethacin for gout. You decide to add a non-purinexanthine oxidase inhibitor to his treatment plan. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.explanation: Febuxostat is a non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is indicated for reducing hyperuricemiain chronic gout. Both allopurinol and febuxostat can be used as first line agents but since thequestion mentions a non-purine inhibitor is chosen, febuxostat is the answer.Option A - Allopurinol is a purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor.Option D - Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent.

questions.question: A patient, who is a known case of gout on treatment with allopurinol, comes to the OPD forfollow up. His serum uric acid level is 11 mg/dl. You add lesinurad to his treatment regime for716adequate disease control. Which group does this drug belong to?
questions.explanation: Lesinurad is a uricosuric agent.It is a URAT1 inhibitor indicated in combination with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor for thetreatment of hyperuricemia associated with gout. By inhibiting URAT1, it increases the urinaryexcretion of uric acid.

questions.question: What is pegloticase used for?
questions.explanation: Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acidinto allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where otherurate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.question: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previoushistory of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migrainemight have caused this presentation?
questions.explanation: 722The patient may have been given sumatriptan, a 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist which causesvasoconstriction and used in migraine. Thus, sumatriptan will worsen angina by causing coronaryvasoconstriction.Angina will be worsened if the O2 demand of the heart is increased or there is reduced blood flowto the already ischemic areas.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in gout?
questions.explanation: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia.The drug of choice in an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)like indomethacin or the drug colchicine. Colchicine is poorly tolerated and should not be usedin elderly patients with chronic kidney disease.Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout. In addition to inhibitingprostaglandin synthase, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosisIntraarticular steroids like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone can also be given.Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric onlyat higher doses that are poorly tolerated.

questions.question: 717A patient was prescribed erenumab-aooe for the prophylaxis of migraine. What is themechanism of action of this drug?

options.A: Parathyroid hormone related protein (PTHrP) receptor agonist
options.B: Parathyroid hormone related protein (PTHrP) receptor antagonist
options.C: Calcitonin gene related protein (CGRP) receptor agonist
options.D: Calcitonin gene related protein (CGRP) receptor antagonistSolution to

questions.explanation: Erenumab-aooe is a calcitonin gene related protein (CGRP) receptor antagonist approved for theprophylaxis of migraine.The pathology of migraine is not completely understood but it includes activation of trigeminalganglion nociceptive neurons and the subsequent release of CGRP from fibers associated withmeningeal vessels. This is believed to mediate vasodilation and mast cell degranulation. Thus,CGRP is involved in the development and maintenance of persistent pain, central sensitizationand allodynia, which are events characteristic of migraine pathology.Blockage of CGRP receptors by CGRP receptor antagonists, causes inhibition of the inflammatoryand nociceptive effects of CGRP at multiple sites within the peripheral and central nervoussystems that are implicated in the underlying pathology of migraine.Monoclonal antibodies that directly inhibit CGRP have also been developed. These include:• Fremanezumab• GalcanezumabNote:The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptorantagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosageis 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal diseaseit is 10 mg once daily.723
